results.title: Spectrum of Brick Lane 2
results.material_description: Lightboxes, steel shelving, acrylic sheet, fluorescent lights, cable and plug boards
results.brief_description: Colour is perceived through light reflected from the object we’re observing. The wavelength of the light determines the hue we see. Batchelor’s illuminated sculpture reminds us of this connection between light and colour, and is inspired by London’s bustling Brick Lane.
results.description: We perceive colour through light reflected from the object we are observing. The wavelength of the light determines the hue we see. Batchelor’s illuminated sculpture reminds us of this connection between light and colour. This work is inspired by the bright windows and signs on Brick Lane, a bustling London street renowned for its South Asian restaurants. Here, light is not connected to spirituality or nature, but is rooted in everyday experiences.
description_for_label: We perceive colour through light reflected from the object we are observing. The wavelength of the light determines the hue we see. Batchelor’s illuminated sculpture reminds us of this connection between light and colour. This work is inspired by the bright windows and signs on Brick Lane, a bustling London street renowned for its South Asian restaurants. Here, light is not connected to spirituality or nature, but is rooted in everyday experiences.

results.title: Lichtspiel Schwarz-Weiss-Grau
results.brief_description:
In 1930, after eight years of research and experimentation, Laszlo Moholy-Nagy created the Light Space Modulator, a kinetic sculpture of rotating glass, spirals and perforated metal sheets illuminated by 140 different light sources. In this same year, he produced the film Lightplay Black White Grey, a dynamic cinematic abstraction of the light and movement generated by the Light Space Modulator. The play of light in the film, as in the original sculpture, enabled Moholy-Nagy to create an altogether new experience for the viewer, asserting his own proposition that,
“Because light is a spatial-temporal problem, the mere accentuation of the question of light brings us into the field of a new spatial awareness that cannot yet be fully analysed. We can, however, find a word to describe it: floating.”
Moholy-Nagy also saw his Light Space Modulator as an extension of the ideas underpinning cinema - magnified light projected on a surface in dynamic configurations. As such, Lightplay Black White Grey, his cinematic mediation of these spatial and light concerns is a vital work in his artistic practise. The film begins as a series of abstract images of geometric shapes and shadows formed by the kinetic movement of the Light Space Modulator. The circular movements of the sculpture and camera in combination provide a pendulous, hypnotic effect that is both a document of the sculpture and an elegant visual dance of shape-shifting forms and transformed light. The rhythmic combinations of stasis and dynamism across altered variations of screen space and superimpositions of motion and form makes for a vertiginous visual experience.
Although it cannot replicate the immersive experience of the light sculpture, the film creates a viewing space in which the audience is visually disoriented by Moholy-Nagy’s spatial dislocations. As the artist anticipated, this creates a sensation of detachment, of ‘floating’, amid a dynamic vision of light’s relationship to spatial understanding.

results.title: Britain's First Light
results.brief_description:
‘First Light’ is a British wide organisation that uses film and media production to develop skills in young people aged up to 25.
Talented youth from a wide range of backgrounds are provided with training led by film and media industry professionals using industry standard equipment. This collection draws works from several years of this creative partnership.

results.title: Until My Heart's, Like, Finished
results.creator_credit: Peter Snelling, Martin Hodgson, Phil Shepherd, First Light and Somerset Film
results.brief_description: On the day of your 16th birthday, your mum kicks you out of home for good. You live in a car. You sofa surf. You sleep rough. Life for these young people has been tough with many challenges. Here they tell their stories in their own words, reveal they have learnt about how to survive and make plans for putting their lives back together.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Peter Snelling, Martin Hodgson, Phil Shepherd, First Light and Somerset Film

results.title: The Race
results.creator_credit: Nikki Rose, First Light and Kinetoscope Productions
results.brief_description: Neil and David met at nursery school. There was something different about Neil but David liked him, even though he often got himself into a bad temper. Neil knew that because of his condition eventually they would part company but David vowed that they would always remain best friends.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Nikki Rose, First Light and Kinetoscope Productions

results.title: Prehistoric Pet Shop
results.creator_credit: Chris Barnard, Mathew Buck, George Ing, Create Studios, Dacoit Studios, Evil Twin Artworks and First Light
results.brief_description: Prehistoric Pet Shop is about a caveman whose alarm clock stops working. But not just any alarm clock - the clock was a bird with an unfortunate heart problem. The caveman goes to the pet shop to complain about his faulty alarm clock. A homage to Monty Python’s parrot sketch, this hilarious short reveals that complaining can get you more than just a new alarm clock.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Chris Barnard, Mathew Buck, George Ing, Create Studios, Dacoit Studios, Evil Twin Artworks and First Light

results.title: Pirates of the Indian Ocean
results.creator_credit: Enamul Khan, Omni Rahman, Rafi Rahman, First Light, Northamptonshire Bangladeshi Association and Wind & Foster Media
results.brief_description: Clumsy but lovable DJ duo Mankind and Small-Steps have built a devoted following to their pirate radio show. Raging against the machine in their own inimitable style, will they reach the top of radio programming or be caught on the wrong side of the law before they reach their dream?
results.creator_credit_for_label: Enamul Khan, Omni Rahman, Rafi Rahman, First Light, Northamptonshire Bangladeshi Association and Wind & Foster Media

results.title: One Week Later
results.creator_credit: Peter Snelling, Rachel Tunnard, Mandy Rathbone, Ferndown Upper School, First Light and PVA Medialab
results.brief_description: Told through the eyes of a younger pupil, who surveys the relationships his brother has with his peer group. As revelations and misunderstandings occur, due to the misuse of the ubiquitous mobile phone, the week’s events come to a climax on a Friday afternoon.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Peter Snelling, Rachel Tunnard, Mandy Rathbone, Ferndown Upper School, First Light and PVA Medialab

results.title: One Man's Walk
results.creator_credit: Kenneth Mitchell, First Light and Interplay Theatre
results.brief_description: A boy walks down a street. We do not see his face. He is the event but we don’t know why. He tells us his likes and dislikes as he passes through the streets of his town. Finally we see his face and understand.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Kenneth Mitchell, First Light and Interplay Theatre
results.description: A boy walks down a street. We do not see his face. He is the event but we don’t know why. He tells us his likes and dislikes as he passes through the streets of his town. Finally we see his face and understand.

results.title: 6.00 PM
results.credit_line: Tate: Purchased using funds provided by the 2006 Outset / Frieze Art Fair Fund to benefit the Tate Collection 2007
results.description: The title 6.00 PM implies that the pattern at the centre of the carpet depicts the play of light and shadow cast through a window at six o’clock in the evening. But the carpet is always displayed in a windowless gallery and the image itself never changes. We can walk across and leave marks on the carpet, meaning we are unlikely to be tricked by the illusion. By fixing a particular moment of light, the work draws attention to connections between light and our perception of time.
description_for_label: The title 6.00 PM implies that the pattern at the centre of the carpet depicts the play of light and shadow cast through a window at six o’clock in the evening. But the carpet is always displayed in a windowless gallery and the image itself never changes. We can walk across and leave marks on the carpet, meaning we are unlikely to be tricked by the illusion. By fixing a particular moment of light, the work draws attention to connections between light and our perception of time.
